[[Statistics Canada]]. Retrieved on 17 April 2009. |- style="text-align:center; background:#abc;" |Ethnic Origin |Percentage |- style="text-align:center;" |English |45.5 |- style="text-align:center; background:#eee;" |Canadian |41.1 |- style="text-align:center;" |Irish |31.3 |- style="text-align:center; background:#eee;" |[[Scottish people|Scottish]] |8.3 |- style="text-align:center;" |French |4.6 |- style="text-align:center; background:#eee;" |German |2.1 |} As of the [[Canada 2006 Census|2006 Census]], there were 100,646 inhabitants in St. John's itself, 151,322 in the urban area and 181,113 in the [[St. John's Metropolitan Area|St. John's Census Metropolitan Area]] (CMA).{{cite web|url=http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census06/data/popdwell/Table.cfm?T=303&CMA=1&S=0&O=A&RPP=25|title= St. John's Census Metropolitan Area (CMA) with census subdivision (municipal) population breakdowns|publisher=Statistics Canada|date=5 November 2008|accessdate=2011-01-23}} Thus, St. John's is Newfoundland and Labrador's largest city and Canada's 20th largest CMA.{{cite web|url=http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census06/data/popdwell/Table.cfm?T=205&SR=1&S=3&O=D&RPP=33 |title=Population and dwelling counts, for census metropolitan areas (ALL), 2006 and 2001 censuses – 100% data |work=[[Statistics Canada]], 2006 Census of Population |date=13 March 2007|accessdate=2007-03-13}} Apart from St. John's, the CMA includes 12 other communities: the city of [[Mount Pearl]] and the towns of [[Conception Bay South]], [[Paradise, Newfoundland and Labrador|Paradise]], [[Portugal Cove-St. Philip's]], [[Torbay, Newfoundland and Labrador|Torbay]], [[Logy Bay-Middle Cove-Outer Cove]], [[Pouch Cove]], [[Flatrock, Newfoundland and Labrador|Flatrock]], [[Bay Bulls, Newfoundland and Labrador|Bay Bulls]], [[Witless Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador|Witless Bay]], [[Petty Harbour-Maddox Cove]] and [[Bauline]]. The population of the CMA was 192,326 as of 1 July 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/91-214-x/2009000/t013-eng.htm |title=Table 1.1–1 Annual population estimates by census metropolitan area, Canada – Population by sex at July 1 |accessdate=2011-02-04 |publisher=Statistics Canada}} As of 2011, there were 4,205 members of [[visible minorities]] in the city. The largest visible minority group were [[South Asian Canadian|South Asians]] (1.2%), followed by [[Chinese Canadians|Chinese Canadian]] (1.0%), and [[Black Canadians|Blacks]] (0.9%). There were 4,305 [[Aboriginal Canadians|Aboriginal]]s in St. John's, comprising 4.1% of the city's population. [[First Nations]] people made up 2.9% of the city's population, [[Inuit]] comprised 0.8% of St. John's population, and 0.6% were [[Métis]].{{cite web|title=NHS Profile, St. John's, CY, Newfoundland and Labrador, 2011 |url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/dp-pd/prof/details/page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo1=CSD&Code1=1001519&Data=Count&SearchText=st.%20john's&SearchType=Begins&SearchPR=01&A1=All&B1=All&Custom=&TABID=1|publisher=[[Statistics Canada]]|accessdate=15 March 2014}} ===Religion=== [[File:St John's Basilica.jpg|thumb|The [[Basilica of St. John the Baptist]] is the seat of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. John's, Newfoundland|Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. John's]]. Catholicism is the largest religion in the city.]] ''The information below is from the [[Canada 2001 Census|2001 Canadian Census]].{{cite web |url=http://www40.statcan.ca/l01/cst01/demo27a.htm |title=Population by selected ethnic origins, by census metropolitan areas (2006 Census) |publisher=0.statcan.ca |date=14 August 2009 |accessdate=2011-12-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018200104/http://www40.statcan.ca/l01/cst01/demo27a.htm |archive-date=18 October 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}'' and the National Household Survey 2011{{cite web|url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/dp-pd/prof/details/page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo1=CSD&Code1=1001519&Data=Count&SearchText=St.%20John%27s&SearchType=Begins&SearchPR=01&A1=All&B1=All&GeoLevel=PR&GeoCode=1001519&TABID=1 |title=National Household Survey (NHS) Profile, 2011 |publisher=2.statcan.gc.ca |date= |accessdate=2015-04-27}} Predominantly Christian, the population of St. John's was once divided along sectarian ([[Catholic]]/[[Protestant]]) lines. In recent years, this sectarianism has declined significantly, and is no longer a commonly acknowledged facet of life in St. John's. St. John's is the seat of the [[Basilica of St. John The Baptist|Roman Catholic Archbishop of St. John's]], and the Anglican [[Cathedral of St. John the Baptist (St. John's)|Bishop of Eastern Newfoundland and Labrador]]. All major Christian sects showed a decline from 2001–2011 with a large increase in those with no religion from 3.9% to 11.1%. {| class="wikitable" |- " !Religion !2001 (%) !2011 (%) !2011 (Total) |- |[[Roman Catholic]] |48.9% |48.4% |50,370 |- |[[Anglican]] |22.8% |16.1% |16,745 |- |[[United Church]] |15.0% |12.8% |13,345 |- |[[Pentecostal]] |2.3% |2.3% |2,390 |- |No religion |3.9% |11.1% |11,505 |} ==Economy== {{See also|List of companies headquartered in St. John's}} [[File:TerraNovaOil.jpg|thumb|An [[oil platform]] in the [[Terra Nova oil field]]. A number of offshore oil developments lie off the coast of St. John's.]] St. John's economy is connected to both its role as the provincial capital of Newfoundland and Labrador and to the ocean. The civil service which is supported by the federal, provincial and municipal governments has been the key to the expansion of the city's labour force and to the stability of its economy, which supports a sizable retail, service and business sector.{{cite web |url=http://www40.statcan.gc.ca/l01/cst01/govt58a-eng.htm?sdi=st%20john%20employment |title=Statistics Canada – Federal government employment, wages and salaries, by census metropolitan area |publisher=0.statcan.gc.ca |date=24 November 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005230634/http://www40.statcan.gc.ca/l01/cst01/govt58a-eng.htm?sdi=st%20john%20employment |archive-date=5 October 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The provincial government is the largest employer in the city, followed by [[Memorial University of Newfoundland|Memorial University]].{{cite web |last=Baker |first=Melvin |title=St. John's |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/st-johns/ |publisher=The Canadian Encyclopedia |accessdate=5 August 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.stjohns.ca/cityhall/pdfs/StatisticalProfileJul2010.pdf |title=Statistical Profile St. John's Metro Area |format=PDF |date=June 2011 |accessdate=5 August 2011 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} With the [[Collapse of the Atlantic northwest cod fishery|collapse of the fishing industry]] in Newfoundland and Labrador in the 1990s, the role of the ocean is now tied to what lies beneath it – oil and gas – as opposed to what swims in or travels across it.{{cite news|url=http://archives.cbc.ca/economy_business/natural_resources/clips/10943/ |title='The Biggest Layoff in Canadian History' |publisher=Archives.cbc.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} The city is the centre of the oil and gas industry in Eastern Canada and is one of 19 World Energy Cities.{{cite web|title=The Partnership|url=http://www.energycities.org/partner-cities|publisher=World Energy Cities Partnership|accessdate=6 April 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306095131/http://www.energycities.org/partner-cities|archivedate=6 March 2012|df=dmy-all}} [[ExxonMobil]] Canada is headquartered in St. John's and companies such as [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]], [[Husky Energy]], [[Suncor Energy]] and [[Statoil]] have major regional operations in the city.{{cite news|title=ExxonMobil Canada moving to St. John's|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2010/07/21/nl-exxonmobile-relocting-721.html|accessdate=3 August 2011|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=21 July 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://investincanada.gc.ca/eng/explore-our-regions/atlantic-canada/newfoundland-and-labrador/st-johns.aspx |title=St. John's Profile |publisher=Invest in Canada |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513203114/http://investincanada.gc.ca/eng/explore-our-regions/atlantic-canada/newfoundland-and-labrador/st-johns.aspx |archive-date=13 May 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Three major offshore oil developments, [[Hibernia oil field|Hibernia]], [[Terra Nova oil field|Terra Nova]] and [[White Rose oil field|White Rose]], are in production off the coast of the city and a fourth development, Hebron, is expected to be producing oil by 2017.{{cite web |url=http://investincanada.gc.ca/eng/explore-our-regions/atlantic-canada/newfoundland-and-labrador.aspx |title=NL Profile |publisher=Invest in Canada |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513203118/http://investincanada.gc.ca/eng/explore-our-regions/atlantic-canada/newfoundland-and-labrador.aspx |archive-date=13 May 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|title=N.L. expects $20B from Hebron oil deal|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2008/08/20/hebron-today.html|accessdate=3 August 2011|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=20 August 2008}} The economy has been growing quickly in recent years. In 2010 and 2011, the metro area's gross domestic product (GDP) led 27 other metropolitan areas in the country, according to the [[Conference Board of Canada]], recording growth of 6.6 per cent and 5.8 per cent respectively.{{cite news|last=MacEachern|first=Daniel|title=St. John's economic growth slowing to crawl|newspaper=The Telegram|date=12 January 2012|pages=D1}} At $52,000 the city's per capita GDP is the second highest out of all major Canadian cities.{{cite web |url=http://www.stjohns.ca/cityhall/pdfs/2010-2013CorporateStrategicPlan.pdf |work=2010 – 2013 Corporate Strategic Plan |title=2.0 The Current Environment |publisher=City of St. John's |page=2 |format=PDF |date=June 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-02 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Economic forecasts suggest that the city will continue its strong economic growth in the coming years not only in the "oceanic" industries mentioned above, but also in tourism and new home construction as the population continues to grow. In May 2011, the city's unemployment rate fell to 5.6 per cent, the second lowest unemployment rate for a major city in Canada.{{cite news|title=History of regional unemployment rates in Canada|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/economy/jobs/history-of-regional-unemployment-rates-in-canada/article1702302/?from=2055169|work=2011-06-10|publisher=Globe and Mail|accessdate=2011-06-11}} St. John's is also becoming known as an entrepreneurial city. In a 2009 report by the Canadian Federation of Independent Business, ''Communities in Boom: Canada’s Top Entrepreneurial Cities'', St. John's was ranked the best major city in Atlantic Canada and 19th overall in Canada for providing a good environment for small business development.{{cite web|last=Wong|first=Queenie|title=Communities in Boom: Canada’s Top Entrepreneurial Cities in 2009|url=http://www.cfib-fcei.ca/english/research/canada/110-economic_development/1320-communities_in_boom__canada%E2%80%99s_top_entrepreneurial_cities.html|publisher=Canadian Federation of Independent Business|accessdate=3 August 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513181652/http://www.cfib-fcei.ca/english/research/canada/110-economic_development/1320-communities_in_boom__canada%E2%80%99s_top_entrepreneurial_cities.html|archive-date=13 May 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Culture== [[File:Water street st. john's2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Water Street, St. John's|Water Street]] is notable for its boutiques and restaurants]] The [[downtown St. John's|downtown]] area is the cultural hub of St. John's and is a major tourist destination in Newfoundland and Labrador and Atlantic Canada. [[Water Street, St. John's|Water Street]] and Duckworth Street are known for their brightly coloured low rise heritage buildings, housing numerous tourist shops, clothing boutiques, and restaurants. [[George Street, St. John's|George Street]], a downtown side-street above the western end of Water Street, is the predominant home of the city's nightlife. It holds numerous annual festivals including the George Street Festival in August and the Mardi Gras Festival in October. The street can be credited with kick-starting the careers of many musical acts and is busy nearly every night of the week.{{cite web|url=http://www.georgestreetlive.ca/about/|title=About George Street|publisher=George Street Entertainment District|accessdate=2011-03-14}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2008/08/06/george-street.html|title=Famous George Street may get makeover, city of St. John's says|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=6 August 2008|accessdate=2011-03-14}} The city has a [[Newfoundland Symphony Orchestra|symphony orchestra]], a string quartet, and several choirs. In addition the School of Music of [[Memorial University of Newfoundland]] has several ensembles, including a chamber orchestra. St. Johns also plays host to the [[Tuckamore Festival]] of chamber music, which has been held every August since 2001. [[Opera on the Avalon]] puts on performances of opera, over several days, in the summer The [[LSPU Hall]] is home to the [[Resource Centre for the Arts]]. The "Hall" hosts a vibrant and diverse arts community and is regarded as the backbone of artistic infrastructure and development in the downtown.{{cite web|title=A Brief History of "The Hall"|url=http://www.rca.nf.ca/pages.aspx?id=3|publisher=Resource Centre for the Arts|accessdate=6 April 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120422040321/http://www.rca.nf.ca/pages.aspx?id=3|archive-date=22 April 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The careers of many well-known Newfoundland artists were launched there including [[Rick Mercer]], [[Mary Walsh (actress)|Mary Walsh]], [[Cathy Jones]], [[Andy Jones (comedian)|Andy Jones]] and [[Greg Thomey]]. The St. John's [[Arts and Culture Centre]] houses an art gallery, libraries and a 1000-seat theatre, which is the city's major venue for entertainment productions.{{cite web|url=http://www.artsandculturecentre.com/stjohns/index.html |title=Arts and Culture Website |publisher=Artsandculturecentre.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} The [[Nickel Film Festival]] and the St. John's International Women's Film Festival are two [[independent film]] festivals held annually in St. John's.{{cite web|url=http://www.womensfilmfestival.com/ |title=womensfilmfestival.com |publisher=womensfilmfestival.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} ===Museums=== [[File:TheRoomsStJohnsNewfoundland.JPG|thumb|Located in downtown St. John's, [[The Rooms]] houses the provincial [[art gallery]] and museum.]] The [[The Rooms|Provincial Museum of Newfoundland and Labrador]] (c. 1892–93) was located on Duckworth Street in a building designated as a heritage site by the City of St. John's.{{CRHP|2331|Provincial Museum of Newfoundland and Labrador|accessdate=2009-07-04}} In 2005 the museum, along with the Art Gallery of Newfoundland and Labrador and the Provincial Archives of Newfoundland and Labrador, moved into [[The Rooms]]. The Rooms is Newfoundland and Labrador's cultural facility, and is located in the downtown area.{{cite web|title=About The Rooms|url=http://www.therooms.ca/abouttherooms.asp|publisher=The Rooms|accessdate=31 July 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130726153127/http://www.therooms.ca/abouttherooms.asp|archive-date=26 July 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Other museums include the [[Railway Coastal Museum]], a transportation museum located in the 104-year-old Newfoundland and Labrador train station building on Water Street.{{cite web|title=The Railway Coastal Museum|url=http://www.railwaycoastalmuseum.ca/|accessdate=2009-09-10}} The [[Johnson Geo Centre]] is a geological interpretation centre located on Signal Hill.{{cite web|title=The Johnson GEO CENTRE|url=http://www.geocentre.ca/|accessdate=2009-10-12}} The centre is designed to teach the public about the history of the earth through the unique and complex geological history of Newfoundland and Labrador. The East Rider Motorcycle Museum showcases over 110 years of Newfoundland's Motorcycle History, with two floors of bikes, memorabilia, and biker culture. Located downtown St. John's (above East Rider Motorcycle Gear Shop). ===National Historic Sites=== [[File:St. John's Newfoundland Time Lapse.JPG|thumb|[[Cabot Tower (Newfoundland)|Cabot Tower]] overlooks the city from [[Signal Hill, Newfoundland and Labrador|Signal Hill]]. The hill was named a [[National Historic Sites of Canada|National Historic Site]] due to its association with Canada's defence and communication history.]] The Murray Premises is a National Historic Site located in downtown St. John's.{{cite web |url=http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/docs/r/system-reseau/sec6/sites-lieux65.aspx |title=Parks Canada's list of Historical Sites in NL |publisher=Pc.gc.ca |date=15 April 2009 |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728175836/http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/docs/r/system-reseau/sec6/sites-lieux65.aspx |archive-date=28 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The buildings once served as a fishery premises, with facilities for drying and packaging fish and warehouses for fish, barrels and other items. The oldest of the buildings is the one facing on Beck's Cove. It was built after the 1846 fire and for a time served as both shop and house. The Murray Premises was renovated in 1979 and now contains office suites, restaurants, retail stores and a boutique hotel.{{cite web|url=http://downtownstjohns.com/discover/attractions/ |title=Downtown St. John's Attractions |publisher=Downtownstjohns.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}}{{cite web |url=http://www.murraypremises.com/history.aspx |title=Murray Premises Hotel History |publisher=Murraypremises.com |date=30 November 1979 |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714133204/http://www.murraypremises.com/history.aspx |archive-date=14 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Another National Historic Site is [[Signal Hill, Newfoundland and Labrador|Signal Hill]] is a hill which overlooks the city of St. John's. It is the location of [[Cabot Tower (Newfoundland)|Cabot Tower]] which was built in 1897 to commemorate the 400th anniversary of [[John Cabot]]'s discovery of Newfoundland, and [[Queen Victoria]]'s Diamond Jubilee. The first transatlantic [[wireless]] transmission was received here by [[Guglielmo Marconi]] on 12 December 1901.Atlantic Cable. [http://www.atlantic-cable.com/NF2001/NF2001Images/NF0127e.jpg IEEE Milestone Plaque] Today, Signal Hill is a [[National Historic Sites of Canada|National Historic Site of Canada]] and remains incredibly popular amongst tourists and locals alike; 97% of all tourists to St. John's visit Signal Hill. Amongst its popular attractions are the Signal Hill Tattoo, showcasing the [[Royal Newfoundland Regiment]] of foot, c. 1795, and the North Head Trail which grants an impressive view of the Atlantic Ocean and the surrounding coast.Parks Canada . [http://www.pc.gc.ca/lhn-nhs/nl/signalhill/index_e.asp Signal Hill National Historic Site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041011090345/http://www.pc.gc.ca/lhn-nhs/nl/signalhill/index_e.asp |date=11 October 2004 }} ===Urban parks=== [[Pippy Park]] is an urban park in the east end of the city; with over {{convert|3400|acre|km2}} of land, it is one of Canada's largest urban parks. The park contains a range of recreational facilities including two golf courses, Newfoundland and Labrador's largest serviced campground, walking and skiing trails as well as protected habitat for many plants and animals. Pippy Park is also home to the [[Fluvarium]], an environmental education centre which offers a cross section view of Nagle's Hill Brook.{{cite web|title=Pippy Park|url=http://pippypark.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=83&Itemid=81/|accessdate=2009-09-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715084901/http://pippypark.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=83&Itemid=81%2F|archive-date=15 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} [[Bowring Park (St. John's)|Bowring Park]], located in the [[Waterford Valley, St. John's|Waterford Valley]], is one of the most scenic parks in St. John's. Entrance to the park is via Waterford Bridge Road, passing a sculptured duck pond and a [[statue of Peter Pan]]. The park land was donated to the city in 1911 by [[Edgar Rennie Bowring|Sir Edgar Rennie Bowring]] on behalf of [[Bowring Brothers]] Ltd. on their 100th anniversary of commerce in Newfoundland. The park was officially opened by His Royal Highness, the [[Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn|Duke of Connaught]] on 15 July 1914.{{cite web|last=Shalev|first=Gil|title=Bowring Park|url=http://www.bowringpark.com/usr/documents/bowringpark_history.pdf|publisher=Bowring Park Foundation|accessdate=3 August 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004172750/http://www.bowringpark.com/usr/documents/bowringpark_history.pdf|archive-date=4 October 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} [[Bannerman Park]] is a Victorian-style park located near the downtown. The park was officially opened in 1891 by [[Alexander Bannerman|Sir Alexander Bannerman]], Governor of the [[Colony of Newfoundland]] who donated the land to create the park.{{cite web |title=St. John's Downtown Development Commission, Local Attractions |url=http://downtownstjohns.com/discover/attractions/ |accessdate=2010-10-20}} Today the park contains a public swimming pool, playground, a baseball diamond and many large open grassy areas. Bannerman Park plays host to many festivals and sporting events, most notably the Newfoundland and Labrador Folk Festival and St. John's Peace-a-chord. The park is also the finishing location for the annual [[Tely 10 Mile Road Race]].{{cite web|title=Tely 10 – Race Course|url=http://www.nlaa.ca/tely10/course.php|publisher=Newfoundland and Labrador Athletic Association|accessdate=31 July 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110827143822/http://www.nlaa.ca/tely10/course.php|archive-date=27 August 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Sports== [[File:Mile one stadium.jpg|thumb|[[Mile One Centre]] is an multi-purpose indoor arena. It is used as the home arena for the [[National Basketball League of Canada|NBLC]]'s [[St. John's Edge]] and the [[ECHL]]'s [[Newfoundland Growlers]].]] ===Hockey=== St. John's has been home to several professional [[ice hockey|hockey]] franchises. The [[St. John's Maple Leafs]] were an [[American Hockey League]] (AHL) team from 1991 to 2005. The team left after the 2004–05 season to [[Toronto]] due to the desire of its parent team, the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]], to reduce travel costs and to have a tenant for its [[Ricoh Coliseum]].{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2004/08/09/babyleafs040809.html |work=CBC News |title=Baby Leafs to leave St. John's after 14 seasons |date=10 August 2004}} Shortly after, the Maple Leafs were replaced by the [[St. John's Fog Devils]] of the [[Quebec Major Junior Hockey League]] (QMJHL). The team left St. John's in 2008 after just three seasons due to a poor lease arrangement with the city over the use of [[Mile One Centre]] and poor attendance.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2008/01/23/fog-devils.html |work=CBC News |title=Fog Devils sold, move planned to Quebec |date=23 January 2008}}{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2010/08/09/nl-stjohns-hockey-.html |work=CBC News |title=Puck may drop at St. John's Mile One |date=9 August 2010}} From 2011 until 2017, it was home to the [[St. John's IceCaps]] in the AHL.{{cite news|title=Still no replacement found for IceCaps at Mile One Centre|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/mile-one-centre-replacement-1.3990824|accessdate=29 May 2017|publisher=CBC|date=20 February 2017}} The IceCaps operated under two separate franchises and affiliations during its time in St John's; the first owned by the [[Winnipeg Jets]]' [[True North Sports & Entertainment]] and the second by the [[Montreal Canadiens]]' [[Molson family]]. Both franchises were relocated to be closer to their parent team. In 2018, the [[ECHL]] approved an expansion team for St. John's with the [[Newfoundland Growlers]] to begin play in the fall of 2018. The team is expected to become the ECHL affiliate of the Toronto Maple Leafs bringing the Leafs back to St. Johns for the first time since 2005. ===Other sports=== [[File:Regatta Start, St. John's, Newfoundland.jpg|thumb|right|St. John's hosts North America's oldest annual sporting event, the [[Royal St. John's Regatta]]]] The [[St. John's Edge]] is a Canadian professional basketball team based in [[National Basketball League of Canada]] that launched as an expansion team for the [[2017–18 NBL Canada season|2017–18 season]] at the Mile One Centre.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/stjohns-deal-national-basketball-league-1.4295504 |title=St. John's city council approves agreement to bring pro basketball to Mile One |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=September 18, 2017}} The team is owned by Atlantic Sport Enterprises Ltd. headed by John Graham with Irwin Simon and Robert Sabbagh.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/irwin-simon-nbl-canada-rob-sabbagh-st-johns-1.4304365 |title=Who is Irwin Simon and why did he buy a basketball team in St. John's? |work=[[CBC News]] |date=September 23, 2017}} The team replaced the IceCaps as the primary tenant at the Mile One Centre after their departure. The [[rugby union]] team [[The Rock (rugby team)|The Rock]] is the Eastern Canadian entry in the [[Americas Rugby Championship]]. The Rock play their home games at [[Swilers Rugby Park]], as did the [[Rugby Canada Super League]] champions for 2005 and 2006, the [[Newfoundland Rock]]. The city hosted a [[Rugby World Cup]] qualifying match between Canada and the USA on 12 August 2006, where the Canadians heavily defeated the USA 56–7 to qualify for the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]] finals in France. The 2007 age-grade Rugby Canada National Championship Festival was held in the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.rockrugby.ca/ |title=Newfoundland and Labrador Rugby Union |publisher=Rockrugby.ca |date=12 August 2006 |accessdate=2011-01-02}} St. John's is home to North America's oldest annual sporting event, the [[Royal St. John's Regatta]], which dates back to at least 1816. The event is important enough in the life of the city that the day of the Regatta (the first Wednesday in August, weather permitting) is a civic holiday – one of the few weather-dependent holidays in the world.{{cite web|author=Andrew G. Reid |url=http://www.stjohnsregatta.org/ |title=The Royal St. John'S Regatta |publisher=Www.Stjohnsregatta.Org |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} The [[Tely 10]] is an annual {{convert|10|mi|km|adj=on}} road race that starts in Paradise and finishes at Bannerman Park. The race draws in excess of 2,500 runners. It began in 1922, which makes it one of the oldest road races in Canada.{{cite web |url=http://www.nlaa.ca/tely10/history.php |title=NLAA TELY 10 | A Brief History |publisher=Nlaa.ca |date=26 July 2009 |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514195926/http://www.nlaa.ca/tely10/history.php |archive-date=14 May 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} St. John's was where the [[Canada men's national soccer team]] qualified for their only [[FIFA World Cup]] on 14 September 1985, when they defeated Honduras 2–1, at [[King George V Park]].{{cite news|last1=Flanagan|first1=Susan|title=A game to remember|url=http://www.thewesternstar.com/Living/2014-07-08/article-3790488/A-game-to-remember/1|accessdate=8 September 2015|work=The Western Star|date=8 July 2014}} [[Curling]] has gained prominence in St. John's over the years. The [[2005 Scott Tournament of Hearts]], the Canadian women's curling championship, was held at Mile One Centre from 19 to 27 February 2005.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2003/08/28/scott030828.html |work=CBC News |title=St. John's hosting 2005 Tournament of Hearts |date=28 August 2003}} The 2006 Olympic gold medalist men's curling team, skipped by [[Brad Gushue]], is based in St. John's at the [[Bally Haly Golf & Curling Club]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2006/02/24/nf_gushue_preview_20060224.html |title=CBC – Gushue rink takes Torino gold |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=23 February 2006 |accessdate=2011-01-02}} Gushue and his team launched a campaign to return the [[Tim Horton's Brier|Brier]] to the province for 2017, a successful bid. They would go on to win the Brier as well as representing Canada at the World Championships three weeks later going undefeated and winning the gold medal. The Brier win was the second for the province (1976) and the second time as event host (1972). The city has two curling clubs, the [[St. John's Curling Club]] and the Bally Haly. The St. John's Avalon Harps are the local [[Hurling]] and [[Gaelic Football]] team, that compete in Canadian GAA events. ==Law and government== {{see also|St. John's City Council|List of mayors of St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador}} St. John's is governed by a [[mayor-council system]], and the structure of the municipal government is stipulated by the City of St. John's Act.{{cite web |url=http://www.stjohns.ca/cityhall/council.jsp |title=St. John's City Council |publisher=Stjohns.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081220141624/http://www.stjohns.ca/cityhall/council.jsp |archivedate=20 December 2008 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.assembly.nl.ca/legislation/sr/statutes/c17.htm |title=City of St. John's Act |publisher=Assembly.nl.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} The [[St. John's City Council]] is a [[Unicameralism|unicameral]] legislative body composed of a [[Mayor of St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|mayor]], deputy mayor and nine councillors. The mayor, deputy mayor and four of the councillors are elected at large while the five other councillors represent geographical wards throughout the city. The mayor and members of the city council serve four-year terms without term limits.{{cite web |url=http://www.stjohns.ca/cityhall/council.jsp |title=The City of St.John's – Mayor and Council Members |publisher=Stjohns.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081220141624/http://www.stjohns.ca/cityhall/council.jsp |archivedate=20 December 2008 |df=dmy-all }} Elections in St. John's are held every four years on the last Tuesday in September. The current city council was elected in the municipal election held on 26 September 2017. The Mayor of St. John's is [[Danny Breen]].{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2008/06/03/mayor-election.html |title=O'Keefe wins mayor's race in St. John's byelection |date=3 June 2008 |accessdate=14 September 2009 |work=CBC News}} The St. John's City Hall, located on New Gower Street, has housed municipal offices and Council Chambers since being officially opened in 1970.{{cite web |url=http://www.stjohns.ca/cityhall/elections/voters/index.jsp |title=The City of St.John's – Municipal Election 2009 |publisher=Stjohns.ca |date=25 September 2009 |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080607141312/http://www.stjohns.ca/cityhall/elections/voters/index.jsp |archive-date=7 June 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} [[File:Confederation Building (front), St. John's, Newfoundland, Canada.jpg|thumb|The province's [[Newfoundland and Labrador House of Assembly|House of Assembly]] meets in St. John's, at [[Confederation Building (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Confederation Building]].]] St. John's served as the capital city of the [[Colony of Newfoundland]] and the [[Dominion of Newfoundland]] before Newfoundland became Canada's tenth province in 1949.{{cite web|url=http://www.newfoundlandlabrador.com/About/FAQ.aspx |title=Frequently asked questions about Newfoundland and Labrador |publisher=Newfoundlandlabrador.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} The city now serves as the capital of [[Newfoundland and Labrador]], therefore the provincial legislature is located in the city.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.nl.ca/aboutnl/confed.htm |title=Confederation Building |publisher=Gov.nl.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513211143/http://www.gov.nl.ca/aboutnl/confed.htm |archivedate=13 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The [[Confederation Building (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Confederation Building]], located on Confederation Hill, is home to the [[Newfoundland and Labrador House of Assembly|House of Assembly]] along with the offices for the [[Newfoundland and Labrador House of Assembly|Members of the House of Assembly]] (MHAs) and Ministers. The city is represented by ten MHAs, four who are members of the governing [[Progressive Conservative Party of Newfoundland and Labrador|Progressive Conservative Party]], three that belong to the [[New Democratic Party of Newfoundland and Labrador|New Democratic Party]] (NDP),{{cite news|title=Kirby first NDP to win in St. John's North|url=http://www.thetelegram.com/News/Local/2011-10-11/article-2774331/Kirby-first-NDP-to-win-in-St.-John%26rsquo%3Bs-North/1|accessdate=15 February 2012|newspaper=The Telegram|date=12 October 2011}} and three that belong to the [[Liberal Party of Newfoundland and Labrador|Liberal Party]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/tom-osborne-joins-liberals-1.1354801 |title=Tom Osborne joins Liberals - Newfoundland & Labrador - CBC News |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=2013-08-29 |accessdate=2015-04-27}} [[Lorraine Michael]], leader of the NDP since 2006, represents the district of [[Signal Hill-Quidi Vidi]].{{cite news|title=NDP celebrates historic gains|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nlvotes2011/story/2011/10/11/nl-michael-reelected-101.html|accessdate=15 February 2012|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=12 October 2011}} St. John's is represented in the House of Commons by two members of Parliament, both from the Liberal Party. Nick Whalen represents St. John's East{{Citation |title=Senators and Members > Members of Parliament > Nick Whalen |publisher=House of Commons of Canada |url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/Parliamentarians/en/members/Nick-Whalen%2888296%29 |access-date=2 March 2016}}{{Citation |title=Find a Member of Parliament - Search Results - St. John's East |publisher=House of Commons of Canada |url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/parliamentarians/en/constituencies/FindMP?textCriteria=St.+John%27s+East |access-date=2 March 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305231816/http://www.parl.gc.ca/parliamentarians/en/constituencies/FindMP?textCriteria=St.+John%27s+East |archive-date=5 March 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} and [[Seamus O'Regan]] represents St. John's South—Mount Pearl.{{Citation |title=Senators and Members > Members of Parliament > Seamus O'Regan |publisher=House of Commons of Canada |url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/Parliamentarians/en/members/Seamus-ORegan%2888299%29 |access-date=2 March 2016}}{{Citation |title=Find a Member of Parliament - Search Results - St. John's South — Mount Pearl |publisher=House of Commons of Canada |url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/parliamentarians/en/constituencies/FindMP?textCriteria=St.+John%27s+South%E2%80%94Mount+Pearl |access-date=2 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}{{dead link|date=July 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The Newfoundland and Labrador office for the regional federal minister is in [[downtown St. John's]]. Regional offices for [[Government of Canada|federal government departments and agencies]] are throughout the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.acoa-apeca.gc.ca/English/Pages/ContactUs.aspx |title=ACOA Regional Contact |publisher=Acoa-apeca.gc.ca |date=14 October 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/e0004342 |title=Fisheries and Oceans Regional Contact |publisher=Nfl.dfo-mpo.gc.ca |date=19 November 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-02}} ===Crime=== [[File:RNC Dodge Intrepid.jpg|thumb|A [[Royal Newfoundland Constabulary]] (RNC) [[police car]] on patrol. The RNC serves as the primary policing body for the metropolitan area.]] Police services for the city are provided by the [[Royal Newfoundland Constabulary]], which serves as the primary policing body of the metropolitan area.{{cite web |url=http://www.rnc.gov.nl.ca/default.htm |title=Royal Newfoundland Constabulary |publisher=Rnc.gov.nl.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101115230642/http://www.rnc.gov.nl.ca/default.htm |archive-date=15 November 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The B Division headquarters of the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] is located in the [[Pleasantville, Newfoundland and Labrador|Pleasantville]] neighbourhood but the RCMP primarily operate in the rest of Newfoundland and Labrador and not St. John's.{{cite web|url=http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/nl/detach/index-eng.htm |title=RCMP – Newfoundland and Labrador Detachments |publisher=Rcmp-grc.gc.ca |date=2 October 2006 |accessdate=2011-01-02}} St. John's has traditionally been one of the safest cities in Canada to live; however, in recent years crime in the city has steadily increased. While nationally crime decreased by 4% in 2009, the total crime rate in St. John's saw an increase of 4%. During this same time [[violent crime]] in the city decreased 6%, compared to a 1% decrease nationally.{{cite web|title=Police-reported crime severity indexes, by census metropolitan area1|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/100720/t100720a3-eng.htm|publisher=Statistics Canada|accessdate=5 August 2011}}{{cite web|title=Police-reported Crime Severity Index values, census metropolitan areas (CMAs)|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/090721/t090721a3-eng.htm|publisher=Statistics Canada|accessdate=5 August 2011}} In 2010 the total crime severity index for the city was 101.9, an increase of 10% from 2009 and 19.2% above the national average. The violent crime severity index was 90.1, an increase of 29% from 2009 and 1.2% above the national average. St. John's had the seventh-highest metropolitan crime index and twelfth-highest metropolitan violent crime index in the country in 2010.{{cite web|title=Police-reported crime severity indexes, by census metropolitan area, 2010|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/110721/t110721b3-eng.htm|publisher=Statistics Canada|accessdate=5 August 2011}} According to Statistics Canada's Juristat reports (1993–2007), the metropolitan area reports an average homicide rate of approximately 1.15 per 100,000 population; an average of two [[homicides]] per year. An all-time high rate of 2.27 was reported in 1993 (four homicides). This figure is far below the national average and ranks amongst the lowest rates for any metropolitan area in Canada.{{cite web |url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2009/03/04/the-most-dangerous-cities-in-canada-overall-crime-score%E2%80%94by-rank/ |title=Macleans – List of Most Dangerous Cities in Canada |publisher=.macleans.ca |date=4 March 2009 |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101224153940/http://www2.macleans.ca/2009/03/04/the-most-dangerous-cities-in-canada-overall-crime-score%E2%80%94by-rank/ |archive-date=24 December 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ==Infrastructure== ===Transportation=== [[File:CCGS Henry Larsen, Medium Icebreaker.jpg|thumb|{{ship|CCGS|Henry Larsen}} in St. John's Harbour, where [[Canadian Coast Guard]] vessels use St. John's as a [[home port]].]] [[File:St. John's Airport Terminal.JPG|thumb|right|[[St. John's International Airport]] serves as the international airport for the metropolitan area. It is the second busiest airport in [[Atlantic Canada]].]] St. John's has a substantial harbour. Among other things, the harbour is the base for the following [[Canadian Coast Guard]] (CCG) ships: * {{ship|CCGS|Ann Harvey}} – icebreaker * {{ship|CCGS|George R. Pearkes}} – icebreaker * {{ship|CCGS|Henry Larsen}} – icebreaker * {{ship|CCGS|Louis S. St-Laurent}} – icebreaker * {{ship|CCGS|Terry Fox}} – icebreaker * {{ship|CCGS|Cygnus}} – patrol vessel * {{ship|CCGS|Leonard J. Cowley}} – multi role * {{ship|CCGS|Sir Wilfred Grenfell}} – multi role St. John's is served by [[St. John's International Airport]] (YYT), located 10 minutes northwest of the downtown core.{{cite web |url=http://www.stjohnsairport.com/index/index.cfm?id=46 |title=St. John's International Airport – Airport Location |publisher=Stjohnsairport.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513210455/http://www.stjohnsairport.com/index/index.cfm?id=46 |archive-date=13 May 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} In 2011, roughly 1,400,000 passengers travelled through the airport making it the second busiest airport in Atlantic Canada in passenger volume.{{cite news|title=2011 a record-breaker for St. John's airport|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2012/01/24/nl-stjohns-airport-124.html|accessdate=30 January 2012|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=24 January 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/51-203-x/2008000/t008-eng.htm |title=Passengers enplaned and deplaned on selected services – Top 50 airports |publisher=Statcan.gc.ca |date=8 October 2009 |accessdate=2011-01-02}} Regular destinations include Halifax, [[Montreal]], [[Ottawa]], [[Toronto]], as well as destinations throughout the province. International locations include [[Dublin]], [[London]], [[Saint Pierre and Miquelon]], [[Glasgow]] and [[Varadero]]. Scheduled service providers include [[Air Canada]], [[Air Canada Jazz]], [[Air Saint-Pierre]], [[Air Transat]], [[United Airlines]], [[Porter Airlines]], [[Provincial Airlines]], [[Sunwing Airlines]] and [[Westjet]].{{cite web |url=http://www.stjohnsairport.com/index/index.cfm?id=89 |title=St. John's International Airport :: Airlines & Destinations |publisher=Stjohnsairport.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513210458/http://www.stjohnsairport.com/index/index.cfm?id=89 |archive-date=13 May 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} St. John's is the eastern terminus of the [[Trans-Canada Highway]] ([[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 1|Route 1]]), one of the longest national highways in the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.transcanadahighway.com/general/transcanadahighway.htm|title=TransCanadaHighway.com Highway Overview|accessdate=2008-05-28}} The divided highway, also known as "Outer Ring Road," runs just outside the main part of the city, with exits to [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 2|Pitts Memorial Drive (Route 2)]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 60|Topsail Road (Route 60)]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 3A|Team Gushue Highway (Route 3A)]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 50|Thorburn Road (Route 50)]], Allandale Road, [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 40|Portugal Cove Road (Route 40)]] and [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 20|Torbay Road (Route 20)]], providing relatively easy access to neighbourhoods served by those streets. [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 2|Pitts Memorial Drive (Route 2)]] runs from Conception Bay South, through the city of Mount Pearl and into downtown St. John's, with interchanges for [[Goulds, Newfoundland and Labrador|Goulds]] (Routes [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 3|3]] and [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 10|10]]), [[Parkway (St. John's)|The Parkway (Columbus Drive)]], [[Water Street (St. John's)|Water Street]] and Hamilton Avenue-New Gower Street. The St. John's Cycling Master Plan was officially launched in July 2009. Its first phase will consist of {{convert|43|km}} of on-road painted bike lanes, signs on an additional {{convert|73|km}} of roadway, the installation of 20 bicycle parking facilities and the addition of bike racks on the fleet of 53 Metrobuses.{{cite web|url=http://www.releases.gov.nl.ca/releases/2009/env/0709n09.htm |title=St. John's Cycling Master Plan to Receive $1.5 Million |publisher=Releases.gov.nl.ca |date=9 July 2009 |accessdate=2011-01-02}} [[Metrobus Transit]] is responsible for public transit in the region.{{cite web|url=http://www.metrobus.com|title=Metrobus Transit. Get On. Be Moved.|accessdate=2008-05-28}} Metrobus has a total of 19 routes, 53 buses and an annual ridership of 3,014,073.{{cite web|url=http://www.metrobus.com/statistics.asp |title=Metrobus Ridership Statistics |publisher=Metrobus.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} Destinations include the [[Avalon Mall]], [[The Village Shopping Centre]], Memorial University, Academy Canada, the College of the North Atlantic, the Marine Institute, the Confederation Building, downtown, [[Stavanger Drive|Stavanger Drive Business Park]], Kelsey Drive, [[Goulds, St. John's|Goulds]], [[Kilbride, St. John's|Kilbride]], Shea Heights, the four hospitals in the city as well as other important areas in St. John's and Mount Pearl.{{cite web|title=Summer Schedules|url=http://www.metrobus.com/routes_summer.asp|publisher=Metrobus Transit|accessdate=5 August 2011}} St. John's was the eastern terminus of the [[Newfoundland Railway]] from 1898 until the abandonment and closure of the railway in September 1988.{{cite web|url=http://www.heritage.nf.ca/society/railway.html |title=Railway: Newfoundland and Labrador Heritage |publisher=Heritage.nf.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} ===Medical centres and hospitals=== St. John's is served by Eastern Health, Newfoundland and Labrador's largest health authority.{{cite web|url=http://www.easternhealth.ca/OurServices.aspx |title=Eastern Health – Our Services |publisher=Eastern Health}} The city's major hospitals include the Health Sciences Centre, St. Clare's Mercy Hospital, Waterford Hospital and the [[Janeway Children's Health and Rehabilitation Centre]].{{cite web|url=http://www.easternhealth.ca/map.aspx |title=Interactive Map of Hospitals |publisher=Eastern Health}} ==Education== [[File:Gushue Hall MUN.jpg|thumb|[[Memorial University of Newfoundland]] is the largest university in Atlantic Canada by enrolment.]] St. John's is served by the [[Eastern School District of Newfoundland and Labrador|Eastern School District]], the largest in Newfoundland and Labrador by student population.{{cite web|url=http://www.esdnl.ca/aboutesd/quickfacts/ |title=Eastern School District Quick Facts |publisher=Esdnl.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} There are 36 primary, elementary and secondary schools in the city of St. John's, including three private schools.{{cite web|url=http://www.esdnl.ca/schools/schooldirectory/ |title=Eastern School District School Directory |publisher=Esdnl.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} St. John's has one school that is part of the province-wide Conseil Scolaire Francophone (CSF), the [[Francophone]] public school district. It has two private schools, [[St. Bonaventure's College]] and Lakecrest Independent.{{cite web|url=http://www.stbons.ca/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=44&Itemid=134 |title=St. Bonaventure's – Who We Are |publisher=Stbons.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lakecrest.ca/?page=about |title=About Lakecrest |publisher=Lakecrest.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} [[Atlantic Canada]]'s largest university, [[Memorial University of Newfoundland]] (MUN), is in St. John's.{{cite web| title = University Profiles (Memorial University of Newfoundland)| publisher = Canada's Higher Education and Careers Guide | url = http://www.canadian-universities.net/Universities/Memorial-University-of-Newfoundland.html| accessdate = 2009-12-16}} MUN provides comprehensive education and grants [[academic degree|degrees]] and its historical strengths in engineering, business, geology, and medicine make MUN one of the top comprehensive universities in Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.mun.ca/programs/ |title=Programs & Courses | Programs |publisher=Mun.ca |date=21 December 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-02}}{{cite web| title = 2008 Comprehensive University Rankings| publisher = [[Maclean's]]| url = http://www.macleans.ca/education/universities/acomprehensive.pdf| format = PDF| accessdate = 2009-12-16| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080528120412/http://www.macleans.ca/education/universities/acomprehensive.pdf| archivedate = 28 May 2008| df = dmy-all}} An online preview of the year ranking in the 19 November 2007 edition of ''Maclean's'' magazine. The [[Fisheries and Marine Institute of Memorial University of Newfoundland]] (MI or simply Marine Institute) is a post-secondary ocean and marine polytechnic in St. John's and is affiliated with Memorial University of Newfoundland. MUN offers the lowest tuition in Canada ($2,644, per academic year).{{cite web|url=http://www.mi.mun.ca/ |title=Fisheries and Marine Institute of Memorial University of Newfoundland |publisher=Mi.mun.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} The [[College of the North Atlantic]] (CNA) is the public college of the province and operates two main campuses in the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.cna.nl.ca/campuses/locations.asp |title=CNA Campuses |publisher=Cna.nl.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} CNA provides career, trade, and university-transfer programs for St. John's residents.{{cite web|url=http://www.cna.nl.ca/about/ |title=Welcome |publisher=Cna.nl.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} The city hosts several private colleges and post-secondary schools; Academy Canada, Eastern College, and Keyin College are the largest of these.{{cite web|url=http://www.ed.gov.nl.ca/edu/postsecondary/privatedir.html |title=Private Training Institution Directory | Education |publisher=Ed.gov.nl.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091008103631/http://www.ed.gov.nl.ca/edu/postsecondary/privatedir.html |archivedate=8 October 2009}} ==Local media== {{Main|Media in St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador}} St. John's has one daily newspaper, ''[[The Telegram]]''.{{cite web|author=CA |url=http://www.thetelegram.com/ |title=The Telegram |publisher=The Telegram |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} Other local papers include ''[[The Muse (student paper)|The Muse]]'', ''[[The Gazette (Newfoundland)|The Gazette]]'', ''[[Le Gaboteur]]'', ''[[The Scope (alternative weekly)|The Scope]]'', ''The Business Post'' and ''The Current''. St. John's also receives the nationally distributed newspaper ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.themuse.ca/ |title=The Muse |publisher=Themuse.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}}{{cite web|url=https://www.mun.ca/gazette/ |title=MUN – Gazette |publisher=Mun.ca |date=1 October 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-02}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gaboteur.ca/journal-francophone/index.aspx |title=Le Gaboteur |publisher=Gaboteur.ca |date=23 November 2010 |accessdate=2011-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110122053445/http://www.gaboteur.ca/journal-francophone/index.aspx |archive-date=22 January 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://thescope.ca/ |title=The Scope |publisher=Thescope.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}} [[CJON-DT]], known on air as "NTV", is an [[independent station]]. The station sublicenses entertainment programming from [[Global Television Network|Global]] and news programming from [[CTV Television Network|CTV]] and Global, rather than purchasing primary broadcast rights. [[Rogers Cable]] has its provincial headquarters in St. John's, and their community channel [[Rogers TV]] airs local shows such as ''Out of the Fog'' and ''One Chef One Critic''. [[CBC Television|CBC]] has its Newfoundland and Labrador headquarters in the city and their television station [[CBNT-DT]] broadcasts from University Avenue. The city is home to 15 AM and FM radio stations, two of which are [[French-language]] stations. St. John's is the only Canadian city served by radio stations whose call letters do not all begin with the letter ''C''. The [[ITU prefix]] ''VO'' was assigned to the [[Dominion of Newfoundland]] before the province joined [[Canadian Confederation]] in 1949, and three [[AM radio|AM]] stations kept their existing call letters. However, other commercial radio stations in St. John's that went to air after 1949 use the same range of prefixes (''CF''–''CK'') currently in use elsewhere in Canada, with the exception of [[VOCM-FM]], which was permitted to adopt the VOCM callsign because of its corporate association with the AM station that already bore that callsign. VO remains in use in [[amateur radio]]. ''allNewfoundlandLabrador'' is the city's daily [[online newspaper]], which focuses on business news from across the province.{{cite web|last1=Bradshaw|first1=James|title=Subscription news site AllNovaScotia expands to Newfoundland|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/subscription-news-site-allnovascotia-expands-to-newfoundland/article28830527/|website=Globe and Mail|publisher=Thomson Reuters|accessdate=13 April 2016}} ==Notable people== {{Main|List of people from St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador}} ==Sister cities== * {{flagicon|Portugal}} [[Ílhavo]], Portugal{{cite web|title=St. Johns (Canadá)|url=http://www.cm-ilhavo.pt/pages/124|publisher=Câmara Municipal de Ílhavo|accessdate=8 September 2015|language=Portuguese}} * {{flagicon|Ireland}} [[Waterford]], Ireland{{cite news|title=Waterford city and St John's, Newfoundland, to be twinned|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/waterford-city-and-st-john-s-newfoundland-to-be-twinned-1.1061907|accessdate=8 September 2015|work=The Irish Times|date=26 June 2002}} ==See also== {{portal|St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador}} * [[List of municipalities in Newfoundland and Labrador]] * [[Mundy Pond, Newfoundland|Mundy Pond]] * [[Parkway (St. John's)]] {{Clear right}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Notes=== {{notelist}} ===Bibliography=== *Harding, Les. {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Orphan|date=August 2010}} '''Suren M. Ayvazyan''' (4 August 1933 – 11 September 2009)[http://aivazyansuren.am/ Biography of Suren Ayvazyan] {{ru icon}} was an [[Armenians|Armenian]] [[geologist]] and public figure. He is the author of several works on [[linguistics]] and the history of [[Armenia]]. ==Works on the history of Armenia== In 1960 Ayvazyan met Russian archaeologist [[Boris Piotrovsky]], who participated in the excavations of the ancient [[Urartu|Urartian]] city of [[Teishebaini]]. Ayvazyan discussed with Piotrovsky whether the mythological ancient Armenia described by [[Movses Khorenatsi]] was real. Boris Piotrovsky said to him, "As a geologist, you know that no natural process leaves no evidence. If, as you argue, Movses Khorenatsi's oldest Armenia is there, please show me an archaeological site in Armenia that confirms it."''Айвазян С. М.'' История России. Армянский след, «Крон-Пресс», Москва, 2000 {{ISBN|5-232-01223-1}} Ayvazyan chose as example an ancient monument of the Bronze Age, [[Metsamor site|Metsamor]], and published a work to demonstrate its relationship with Armenia,''Айвазян С. М.'' Известия Академии Наук Армянской ССР, серия Науки о Земле, XVII, 6, Ереван, 1964where he made a false description of coins with alleged [[Hayasa]]n characters. He ascribed them to the 19th century BC and provided his own 'translation'. After checking in the Department of [[Numismatics]] of the Historical Museum of Armenia in 1968, he found that these coins were issued by the [[Atabeg]] dynasty of Azerbaijan in the period 1133-1225).''[[Boris Piotrovsky]]'' Письмо в редакцию // Историко-филологический журнал, Ереван, № 3, 1971 In the same article, Ayvazyan described the ''Hayasian inscription'' found on the rocks of Metsamor, which, after inspection conducted in 1968 by Professor V. Krachkovsky, was thought to be symbols of the [[Thuluth]] [[Arabic alphabet]] of the 19th century. This falsification, however, found its way into some renowned scientific journals, including the Czechoslovak ''New Orient'' (B. Mkrtchian, "The Mystery of Metsamor," No. 3, VI, 1967) and Anatolian Studies(Volume XVIII, 1968), as well as into popular publications of Armenia: the newspaper Komsomolets (November 15, 1968) and the magazine Garun (No. 1, 1969). In these publications Ayvazyan argues:
{| class="wikitable" |Finally, we found, together with a group of geologists Hayasian archaeological site Metsamor with its development Mining Metallurgy production and hieroglyphic writing system did not leave any doubt about the localization Hayasa within Ararat region of Armenia. Evidence of that is the Metsamor Hayasian (ie ancient), rather than any other monument of culture, are found here in the first Armenian hieroglyphic writing. Their decoding of the authors on the basis of correlation with the Armenian hieroglyphic marks, preserved in several medieval manuscripts of Matenadaran. It ceased to exist centenary misunderstanding - the concept of the state of [[Urartu]]. |}
Thus, Ayvazyan created a theory of the Armenian origins of Urartu, with the support of the abovementioned "evidence" of material culture and the discredited attempt at translating the Urartian cuneiform inscriptions into Armenian.{{clarify|date=January 2012}} As a matter of fact, [[Boris Piotrovsky]] noted that, by carrying out this work, Ayvazyan was unaware that he was replicating work done by A. Mordtmann in the 19th century, who tried to read the Urartian cuneiform inscriptions in Armenian.''Mordtmann A.D.'' Über die Keilinschriften von Armenien // Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft, Leipzig, XXXI, 1877 "a work that has been rejected by science long time ago." Despite the disclosure of the falsification, Suren Ayvazyan continued publishing the results of his 'studies' in the popular press, and in books, both in Armenian and in Russian, from the 1980s to the late 2000s. ==Works on the History of Russia== Ayvazyan published a series of surprising assertions regarding the history of Russia. In particular, he argued that the birthplace of the Proto-Russian was the Armenian Highlands in the 11th millennium BC. He also argued that Armenian Smbat Bargatuni founded [[Kiev]], that the Christian churches of Kiev and Novgorod were built by Armenian architects in the 10th to the 11th centuries, that the Armenians introduced Christianity to Russia, and that the real name of [[Yuri Dolgoruki]] was Gevorg Bagratuni. These opinions, according to Ayvazyan, are related to the fact that Mount Small Ararat is formed like a female breast. The other name for this mountain ''Sys'', in Russian, is short for the female breast.{{clarify|date=January 2012}} It is also related to the alleged (but not documented in the scientific literature) detection in the Armenian highlands of 'Slavic skulls', dated by Ayvazyan as the second millennium BC. However, a large part of his claims are based only on many linguistic parallels and archaeological research. ==Socio-political activities== In the years of the Soviet perestroika, Ayvazian was active in the [[Popular Front for Armenia]], and signed a number of letters to [[Mikhail Gorbachev]], then the head of the Soviet state, about the transfer of the [[Nagorno-Karabakh]] region to [[Armenia]]. In 2001 he wrote a letter to [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|British Queen Elizabeth II]] to demand the return of Armenian treasures, consisting of the treasures of Cilicia, which according to some information [[Leo V, King of Armenia|Levon VI]] left in the possession of the [[Edward III of England|English King Edward III]] (1327–1377).[http://english.pravda.ru/culture/2001/05/10/4992.html Новость сайта Pravda.ru от 10 мая 2001 года][http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=264720 Газета «КоммерсантЪ» № 81 (2211) от 15.05.2001. Англичане — это армяне. И Британия должна Армении много денег.] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ayvazyan, Suren}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:Armenian geologists]] [[Category:Pseudohistorians]]

News|Yahoo! News Spain]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130930024446/http://es.noticias.yahoo.com/wakolda-filme-mengele-argentina-elegido-precandidato-%C3%B3scar-172746605.html|archivedate=30 September 2013}} infamous for performing [[Nazi human experimentation|human experiments]] in the [[Auschwitz concentration camp]]. It also stars Florencia Bado, [[Natalia Oreiro]], [[Diego Peretti]], [[Elena Roger]], and Guillermo Pfening.{{cite web|url=http://www.wakolda.com/eng/elenco.html|title=Cast|accessdate=29 September 2013|publisher=''Wakolda'' official website}} ==Plot== [[Josef Mengele]] is in exile in Argentina in 1960, living under a new identity. He makes a long journey by road to a new location by following a family, as the roads are dangerous. Mengele has his own place to stay in [[Patagonia]], but he takes an interest in Lilith, the daughter of the family, and he moves into their hotel by paying six months' rent. Lilith was born prematurely and, as a result, she is much shorter than her classmates. She is bullied at school because of her size. Mengele is working as a doctor and suggests that he can help her grow more quickly, and Lilith's mother Eva agrees to this. Meanwhile, people who have been searching for Mengele believe that they have found him and begin to gather evidence on his true identity. Eva is pregnant with twins, to Mengele's fascination. He compiles copious notes on them, Lilith, and the rest of her family as he continues to aid in her growth. Lilith becomes sick as a side effect of the growth hormones that Mengele has given her. Her father Enzo finds out the truth; he is furious and demands that Mengele leave the hotel. Eva goes into labour, and Mengele is the only doctor nearby and is allowed to help with the care of the newborn twins. They are born prematurely, and Mengele starts experiments to ensure their survival. He is conscious of the fact that people are trying to find his true identity, and when he's almost caught, he escapes the remote location on a seaplane. ==Cast== * [[Àlex Brendemühl]] as [[Josef Mengele]] alias Helmut Gregor * Florencia Bado as Lilith * [[Diego Peretti]] as Enzo * [[Natalia Oreiro]] as Eva * [[Elena Roger]] as Nora Eldoc * Guillermo Pfening as Klaus * Alan Daicz as Tomás * [[Ana Pauls]] as Nurse * Abril Braunstein as Ailín * Juani Martínez as Otto ==Release== It was screened in the [[Un Certain Regard]] section at the [[2013 Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.fr/en/article/59652.html |title=2013 Official Selection|date=15 May 2013|accessdate=15 May 2013|work=Cannes}} The film was selected as the Argentine entry for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[86th Academy Awards]],{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/oscars-argentina-nominates-wakolda-foreign-638296 |title=Oscars: Argentina Nominates 'Wakolda' for Foreign Language Oscar |accessdate=28 September 2013 |work=Hollywood Reporter}}{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2013/film/international/argentina-chooses-german-doctor-aka-wakolda-for-oscar-race-1200674023/ |title=Argentina Chooses ‘German Doctor’ (aka ‘Wakolda’) for Oscar Race |accessdate=29 September 2013 |work=Variety}}{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/09/argentina-calls-on-the-german-doctor-as-foreign-language-oscar-entry/ |title=Argentina Calls On ‘The German Doctor’ As Foreign Language Oscar Entry |accessdate=29 September 2013 |work=Deadline}} but it was not nominated. ==Reception== The film received positive reviews from critics. It currently holds a 73% rating on the [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on 59 reviews, with an average score of 5.7/10. The site's consensus reads, "''The German Doctor'' applies a refreshing level of restraint to its intriguing premise, and boasts solid performances from a talented cast." ===Awards and nominations=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! '''Syria''':
Hundreds of casualties{{cite web |url=http://dover.idf.il/NR/rdonlyres/0771A94F-B23C-43E6-8955-9630D34B8076/0/WarofAttrition40Years.ppt#262,6 |title=The War: Lebanon and Syria |publisher=Dover.idf.il |date= |accessdate=2013-03-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324150613/http://dover.idf.il/NR/rdonlyres/0771A94F-B23C-43E6-8955-9630D34B8076/0/WarofAttrition40Years.ppt#262,6 |archivedate=March 24, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} }} {{Campaignbox War of Attrition}} The '''War of Attrition''' ({{lang-ar|حرب الاستنزاف}} ''Ḥarb al-Istinzāf'', {{lang-he|מלחמת ההתשה}} ''Milhemet haHatashah'') involved fighting between [[Israel]] and [[Egypt]], [[Jordan]], [[PLO]] and their allies from 1967 to 1970. Following the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], no serious diplomatic efforts tried to resolve the issues at the heart of the [[Arab–Israeli conflict]]. In September 1967, the Arab states formulated the "[[Khartoum Resolution|three nos]]" policy, barring peace, recognition or negotiations with Israel. Egyptian President [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] believed that only military initiative would compel Israel or the [[international community]] to facilitate a full Israeli withdrawal from [[Sinai]],{{Cite journal |title = Egypt Will Fight, Nasser Shouts|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|date=November 24, 1967|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19671124&id=iy4NAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mmwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7156,4781952|page=2 |postscript = }} and hostilities soon resumed along the [[Suez Canal]]. These initially took the form of limited artillery duels and small-scale incursions into Sinai, but by 1969 the [[Egyptian Army]] judged itself prepared for larger-scale operations. On March 8, 1969, Nasser proclaimed the official launch of the War of Attrition, characterized by large-scale shelling along the Suez Canal, extensive aerial warfare and [[commando]] raids.{{cite book|last=Aloni|first=Shlomo|title=Israeli Mirage and Nesher Aces|publisher=Osprey|year=2004|pages=46–53}} Hostilities continued until August 1970 and ended with a ceasefire, the frontiers remaining the same as when the war began, with no real commitment to serious peace negotiations. ==Egyptian front== [[Israel]]'s victory in the [[Six-Day War]] left the entirety of the Egyptian [[Sinai Peninsula]] up to the eastern bank of the Suez Canal under Israeli control. Egypt was determined to regain Sinai, and also sought to mitigate the severity of its defeat. Sporadic clashes were taking place along the cease-fire line, and Egyptian missile boats sank the Israeli destroyer [[HMS Zealous (R39)|INS ''Eilat'']] on October 21 of the same year. Egypt began shelling Israeli positions along the [[Bar Lev Line]], using heavy artillery, [[Mikoyan|MiG]] aircraft and various other forms of [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] assistance with the hope of forcing the [[Israeli government]] into concessions.{{cite web | url = http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-219430/Israel | title = Israel: The War of Attrition | accessdate = March 3, 2007 | work = Encyclopædia Britannica }} Israel responded with aerial bombardments, airborne raids on Egyptian military positions, and aerial strikes against strategic facilities in Egypt. The international community and both countries attempted to find a diplomatic solution to the conflict. The [[Jarring Mission]] of the United Nations was supposed to ensure that the terms of [[UN Security Council Resolution 242]] would be observed, but by late 1970 it was clear that this mission had been a failure. Fearing the escalation of the conflict into an "[[Warsaw Pact|East]] vs. [[NATO|West]]" confrontation during the tensions of the mid-[[Cold War]], the American president, [[Richard Nixon]], sent his Secretary of State, [[William P. Rogers|William Rogers]], to formulate the [[Rogers Plan]] in view of obtaining a ceasefire. In August 1970, Israel, [[Jordan]], and Egypt agreed to an "in place" ceasefire under the terms proposed by the Rogers Plan. The plan contained restrictions on missile deployment by both sides, and required the cessation of raids as a precondition for peace. The Egyptians and their Soviet allies rekindled the conflict by violating the agreement shortly thereafter, moving their missiles near to the Suez Canal, and constructing the largest anti-aircraft system yet implemented at that point in history.{{cite web | url = https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/myths/mf8.html | title = Myths & Facts Online: The War of Attrition, 1967–1970 | accessdate =March 3, 2007 | last = Bard | first = Mitchell | publisher = Jewish Virtual Library }} The Israelis responded with a policy which their Prime Minister, [[Golda Meir]], dubbed "[[Asymmetric warfare|asymmetrical response]]", wherein Israeli retaliation was disproportionately large in comparison to any Egyptian attacks. Following Nasser's death in September 1970, his successor, [[Anwar Al-Sadat]], continued the ceasefire with Israel, focusing on rebuilding the [[Egyptian army]] and planning a full-scale attack on the Israeli forces controlling the eastern bank of the Suez Canal. These plans would materialize three years later in the [[Yom Kippur War]]. Ultimately, Israel would return Sinai to Egypt after the two nations signed a [[Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty|peace treaty]]. Various military historians have commented on the war with differing opinions. [[Chaim Herzog]] notes that Israel withstood the battle and adapted itself to a "hitherto alien type of warfare."Herzog (1982), 220 [[Ze'ev Schiff]] notes that though Israel suffered losses, she was still able to preserve her military accomplishments of 1967 and that despite increased Soviet involvement, Israel had stood firm.Schiff, Ze'ev, ''History of the Israeli Army'', Straight Arrow Books (1974), p. 253 Simon Dunstan notes that, although Israel continued to hold the Bar Lev Line, the war's conclusion "led to a dangerous complacency within the Israeli High Command about the resolve of the Egyptian armed forces and the strength of the Bar-Lev Line." On the tactical level, [[Kenneth Pollack]] notes that Egypt's commandos performed "adequately" though they rarely ventured into risky operations on a par with the daring of Israel's commandos,{{sfn|Pollack|2002|page=95}} Egypt's artillery corps encountered difficulty in penetrating the Bar-Lev forts and eventually adopted a policy of trying to catch Israeli troops in the exterior parts of the forts.{{sfn|Pollack|2002|page=94}} The Egyptian Air Force and Air Defense Forces performed poorly.{{sfn|Pollack|2002|page=95}} Egyptian pilots were rigid, slow to react and unwilling to improvise.{{sfn|Pollack|2002|page=96}} According to U.S. intelligence estimates, Egypt lost 109 aircraft, most in air-to-air combat, while only 16 Israeli aircraft were lost, most to anti-aircraft artillery or [[Surface-to-air missile|SAMs]].{{sfn|Pollack|2002|page=96}} It took a salvo of 6 to 10 [[SA-2 Guideline|SA-2]] Egyptian anti-aircraft missiles to obtain a better than fifty percent chance of a hit.{{sfn|Pollack|2002|page=96}} ==Timeline== ===1967=== [[File:Mastvic.jpg|thumb|Israeli naval personnel celebrate their victory after an engagement with Egyptian naval forces near [[Battle of Rumani Coast|Rumani.]]]] '''July 1, 1967''': An Egyptian commando force from Port Fuad moves south and takes up a position at Ras el 'Ish, located 10 miles south of Port Said on the eastern bank of the Suez Canal, an area controlled by the Israelis since the ceasefire on June 9, 1967. An Israeli armored infantry company attacks the Egyptian force. The Israeli company drives off the Egyptians but loses 1 dead and 13 wounded.Herzog, Chaim, ''The Arab-Israeli Wars'', Random House, (New York, 1982), 196 However, another source claims that an Israeli attack on Port Fuad was repulsed. According to [[Zeev Maoz]], the battle was decided in favor of the Egyptians.{{cite book|last1=Maoz|first1=Zeev|authorlink=Zeev Maoz|title=Defending the Holy Land|date=2006|publisher=University of Michigan Press|isbn=0472115405|page=[https://books.google.no/books?id=bWEV__6BYPgC&pg=PA115 115]|language=en}} '''July 2, 1967''': The [[Israeli Air Force]] bombs Egyptian artillery positions that had supported the commandos at Ras Al-'Ish.El Gamasy, ''The October War, 1973'' p.99 '''July 4, 1967''': [[Egyptian Air Force]] jets strike several Israeli targets in Sinai. An Egyptian [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-17|MiG-17]] is shot down.{{cite web|url=http://www.acig.org/artman/publish/article_263.shtml |title=War of Attrition, 1969–1970 |publisher=Acig.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-12}} '''July 8, 1967''': An Egyptian Air Force [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21|MiG-21]] is shot down by Israeli air defenses while on a reconnaissance mission over el-Qanatra. Two [[Sukhoi Su-7|Su-7s]] equipped with cameras are then sent out to carry out the mission, and manage to complete several turns over Sinai without any opposition. Two other Su-7s are sent for another reconnaissance mission hours later, but are attacked by [[Israeli Air Force]] fighter jets. One Su-7 is shot down. '''July 11–12, 1967''': [[Battle of Rumani Coast]] - The [[Israeli Navy]] destroyer [[HMS Zealous (R39)|INS ''Eilat'']] and two [[torpedo boat]]s sink two Egyptian torpedo boats off the Rumani coast. No crewmen on the Egyptian torpedo boats are known to have survived, and there were no Israeli casualties.{{cite web|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Society_&_Culture/navywar.html |title=The Israel Navy Throughout Israel's Wars |publisher=Jewishvirtuallibrary.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-12}} '''July 14, 1967''': Artillery exchanges and aerial duels erupt near the Suez Canal. Seven Egyptian fighter aircraft are shot down.Rothrock, James, Live by the Sword: Israel’s Struggle for existence in the Holy Land, WestBow Press (2011) 48–49 '''July 15, 1967''': An Israeli Air Force [[Dassault Mirage III|Mirage III]] is shot down by an Egyptian [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21|MiG-21]].[http://www.acig.info/CMS/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=185&Itemid=47 Egyptian Air-to-Air Victories since 1948] [[File:INSEilat.jpg|thumbnail|Israeli destroyer INS ''Eilat'' that was sunk by the [[Egyptian Navy]], killing forty-seven sailors.]] '''October 21, 1967''': Two [[Komar-class missile boat|missile boats]] from the [[Egyptian Navy]] sinks the Israeli destroyer INS ''Eilat'' with anti-ship missiles, killing forty-seven sailors. '''October, 1967''': In retaliation to the sinking of the ''Eilat'', Israeli artillery bombards oil refineries and depots near [[Suez]]. In a series of artillery exchanges throughout October, the Egyptians sustain civilian casualties. Egypt evacuates a large number of the civilian population in the canal region.El Gamasy, ''The October War, 1973'' p.101 === 1968 === [[File:Karama aftermath 1.jpg|thumb|left|[[Hussein of Jordan|King Hussein]] after checking an abandoned Israeli tank in the aftermath of the [[Battle of Karameh]] in 1968]] [[File:President Nasser's visit to the Suez front with Egypt's top military commanders during the War of Attrition.jpg|thumb|right|[[Gamal Abdel Nasser|President Nasser]] of Egypt (with binoculars), surveys positions at the Suez Canal in November 1968]] '''March 21, 1968''': In response to persistent PLO raids against Israeli civilian targets, Israel [[Battle of Karameh|attacks]] the town of [[Karameh]], Jordan, the site of a major PLO camp. The goal of the invasion was to destroy Karameh camp and capture [[Yasser Arafat]] in reprisal for the attacks by the PLO against Israeli civilians, which culminated in an Israeli school bus hitting a mine in the Negev.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=hI844N9leNUC&pg=PA45&dq=karameh+battle#v=onepage&q=karameh%20battle&f=false|accessdate=2015-10-25|title=The Arab-Israeli Conflict|author=Cath Senker |year=2004|publisher=Black Rabbit Books|isbn=9781583404416}} However, plans for the two operations were prepared in 1967, one year before the bus incident. {{Cite news| title = Debacle in the desert| work = Haaretz| accessdate = 2011-05-13| date = 1968-03-29| url = http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/week-s-end/debacle-in-the-desert-1.361453}} When Jordan saw the size of the raiding forces entering the battle it was led to the assumption that Israel had another goal of capturing [[Balqa Governorate]] to create a situation similar to the [[Golan Heights]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nQXtz41f-kcC&pg=PT242&lpg=PT242&dq=Israel+assumed+that+the+Jordanian+Army+would+ignore+the+invasion#v=onepage&q=Israel%20assumed%20that%20the%20Jordanian%20Army%20would%20ignore%20the%20invasion&f=false|title=Fortress
